info.title: BloodHound API
info.description:
This is the API that drives BloodHound Enterprise and Community Edition.
Endpoint availability is denoted using the `Community` and `Enterprise` tags.

Contact information listed is for BloodHound Enterprise customers. To get help with
BloodHound Community Edition, please join our
[Slack community](https://ghst.ly/BHSlack/).

## Authentication

The BloodHound API supports two kinds of authentication: JWT bearer tokens and Signed Requests.
For quick tests or one-time calls, the JWT used by your browser may be the simplest route. For
more secure and long lived API integrations, the recommended option is signed requests.

### JWT Bearer Token

The API will accept calls using the following header structure in the HTTP request:
```
Authorization: Bearer $JWT_TOKEN
```
If you open the Network tab within your browser, you will see calls against the API made utilizing
this structure. JWT bearer tokens are supported by the BloodHound API, however it is recommended
they only be used for temporary access. JWT tokens expire after a set amount of time and require
re-authentication using secret credentials.

### Signed Requests

Signed requests are the recommended form of authentication for the BloodHound API. Not only are
signed requests better for long lived integrations, they also provide more security for the
requests being sent. They provide authentication of the client, as well as verification of request
integrity when received by the server.

Signed requests consist of three main parts: The client token ID, the request timestamp, and a
base64 encoded HMAC signature. These three pieces of information are sent with the request using
the following header structure:

```
Authorization: bhesignature $TOKEN_ID
RequestDate: $RFC3339_DATETIME
Signature: $BASE64ENCODED_HMAC_SIGNATURE
```

To use signed requests, you will need to generate an API token. Each API token generated in the
BloodHound API comes with two parts: The Token ID, which is used in the `Authorization` header,
and the Token Key, which is used as part of the HMAC hashing process. The token ID should be
considered as public (like a username) and the token key should be considered secret (like a
password). Once an API token is generated, you can use the key to sign requests.

For more documentation about how to work with authentication in the API, including examples
of how to generate an API token in the BloodHound UI, please refer to this support doc:
[Working with the BloodHound API](https://bloodhound.specterops.io/integrations/bloodhound-api/working-with-api).

#### Signed Request Pseudo-code Example

First, a digest is initiated with HMAC-SHA-256 using the token key as the digest key:
```python
digester = hmac.new(sha256, api_token_key)
```

OperationKey is the first HMAC digest link in the signature chain. This prevents replay attacks that
seek to modify the request method or URI. It is composed of concatenating the request method and
the request URI with no delimiter and computing the HMAC digest using the token key as the digest
secret:
```python
# Example: GET /api/v2/test/resource HTTP/1.1
# Signature Component: GET/api/v2/test/resource
digester.write(request_method + request_uri)

# Update the digester for further chaining
digester = hmac.New(sha256, digester.hash())
```

DateKey is the next HMAC digest link in the signature chain. This encodes the RFC3339
formatted datetime value as part of the signature to the hour to prevent replay
attacks that are older than max two hours. This value is added to the signature chain
by cutting off all values from the RFC3339 formatted datetime from the hours value
forward:
```python
# Example: 2020-12-01T23:59:60Z
# Signature Component: 2020-12-01T23
request_datetime = date.now()
digester.write(request_datetime[:13])

# Update the digester for further chaining
digester = hmac.New(sha256, digester.hash())
```

Body signing is the last HMAC digest link in the signature chain. This encodes the
request body as part of the signature to prevent replay attacks that seek to modify
the payload of a signed request. In the case where there is no body content the
HMAC digest is computed anyway, simply with no values written to the digester:
```python
if request.body is not empty:
  digester.write(request.body)
```

Finally, base64 encode the final hash and write the three required headers before
sending the request:
```python
encoded_hash = base64_encode(digester.hash())
request.header.write('Authorization', 'bhesignature ' + token_id)
request.header.write('RequestDate', request_datetime)
request.header.write('Signature', encoded_hash)
```

servers.description: This is the base path for all endpoints, relative to the domain where the API is being hosted.

post.description: Login to BloodHound with user credentials or a one time password.

requestBody.description: The request body for logging into the application. `secret` *or* `otp` is required, but not both.

login_method.description: The type of login. Currently only `secret` is supported.

secret.description: The password for the user. This field can be used instead of `otp`.

otp.description: The One Time Password for a single login. This field can be used instead of `secret`

post.description: Logout of BloodHound and delete the user session JWT.

200.description:
**Success**
This response will contain no response body.

Location.description: This is the location you will be redirected to after logging out.

get.description: Get the currently authenticated requester details. For Community, this will only ever be valid for users. In Enterprise, this could be either a BloodHound user or a client (collector).
**Deprecated**: This endpoint will no longer be supported in a future release. Please use `GET /api/v2/sso-providers` instead.

get.summary: Get all SAML sign on endpoints

name.description: Name of the new SAML provider.

enabled.description: boolean that, if enabled, allows SSO providers to auto provision bloodhound users on initial login

default_role_id.description: default role id for the user created from SSO provider auto provision

role_provision.description: boolean that, if enabled, allows sso providers to manage roles for newly created users

Retrieve a list of all custom node configurations.
This endpoint returns the current set of registered node kinds and their display settings.

post.description:
This endpoint registers new node kinds along with optional display metadata such as icons and colors.
The provided configuration controls how nodes of the specified kinds are interpreted and rendered in the UI.
Only free, solid-style Font Awesome icons are supported. Hex color codes must follow the format #RGB or #RRGGBB.
If no valid icon or color is provided, the system will fall back to a question mark icon and a white background color.
Batch input is supported; you may submit multiple configuration objects in a single request.

get.description:
Retrieve the configuration for a specific custom node kind.
Returns the display settings and metadata for the requested node kind.

put.description:
This endpoint updates an existing node kind along with optional display metadata such as icons and colors.
The provided configuration controls how nodes of the specified kinds are interpreted and rendered in the UI.
Only free, solid-style Font Awesome icons are supported. Hex color codes must follow the format #RGB or #RRGGBB.
If no valid icon or color is provided, the system will fall back to a question mark icon and a white background color.

delete.description: Delete the configuration for a specific custom node kind.

get.description: Returns the supported API versions.
Returns an Open API 3.0 compatible BloodHound API spec
Search for graph objects by name or object ID, filtered by type.

parameters.name: q
parameters.description: Search parameter for the name or object ID of a node.

parameters.name: type
parameters.description:
Node type. Currently only supports built-in types.
Some AD examples: `Base`, `User`, `Computer`, `Group`, `Container`.
Some Azure examples: `AZBase`, `AZApp`, `AZDevice`.

get.description: Gets available domains along with their collection status
Returns a list of audit logs.

parameters.name: before
parameters.description: Return logs created before the specified time. Value should be in the RFC-3339 format. If not supplied, this will default to the current time.

parameters.name: after
parameters.description: Return logs created after the specified time. Value should be in the RFC-3339 format. If not supplied, this will default to 1 year before the current time.

parameters.name: status
parameters.description: Filter results by column value. Valid filter predicates are `eq`, `neq`. Valid values are `success` and `failure`.

post.description: Sample preview of members selected by provided selector seeds.

requestBody.description: The request body of seeds for previewing what a selector will select.

expansion.description: Determine which expansion approach to use for member seeds. 0 - No expansion, 1 - Expand all, 2 - Expand containing members, 3 - Expand containing members and members containing the seed. Default fallback will be 1 - Expand all

source.description: Describes which phase of tagging resulted in this member being tagged, 1 - direct object, 2 - expanded downward, 3 - expanded upward

post.description: Supports searching by name on asset group tags and selectors, and by name or object ID on members.

requestBody.description: The request body for searching asset group tags. `query` represents being able to query by either name or object id. `tag_type` can be either 1(zone), 2(label), or 3(owned). And `asset_group_tag_id` is the ID of a tag (zone or label).

parameters.name: created_at
parameters.description: For example, you can filter a date range of records by doing `created_at=gt:2025-07-08T17:00:00Z&created_at=lt:2025-07-30T17:00:00Z` (UTC)

get.description: Gets kinds
DEPRECATED use GetShortestPath instead. Get the result of pathfinding between two nodes in graph format.
Get the result of searching a graph for a node by name

parameters.name: type
parameters.description: The type of search strategy to use. Default is `fuzzy`.

get.description: A graph of the shortest path from `start_node` to `end_node`.

parameters.name: relationship_kinds
parameters.description: Specific relationship kinds to include in the pathfinding search. If the kinds are not valid kinds, the query will error.

parameters.name: only_traversable
parameters.description: Whether or not to only include traversable kinds. If true and no `relationship_kinds` are specified, all traversable kinds will be searched. If true, and `relationship_kinds` param includes non-traversable kinds, the non-traversable kinds will be excluded from the path search. If false or omitted, all kinds will be searched.

200.description: A graph of the shortest path from `start_node` to `end_node`.

get.description: Returns a graph representing the various nodes and edges that make up the complex post-processed edge.

parameters.name: source_node
parameters.description: The ID of the starting node.

parameters.name: target_node
parameters.description: The ID of the ending node.

parameters.name: edge_type
parameters.description: The type of edge to show the composition for.

200.description: Returns graph data that contains a collection of nodes and edges related to the composition of the edge queried.

get.description: Returns a graph representing the various nodes that are valid relay targets for this edge

parameters.name: source_node
parameters.description: The ID of the starting node.

parameters.name: target_node
parameters.description: The ID of the ending node.

parameters.name: edge_type
parameters.description: The type of edge to show the composition for.

200.description: Returns graph data that contains a collection of nodes that are valid relay targets related to the composition of the edge queried.

get.description: Returns a graph representing the path that an ACE is inherited through for a given edge.

parameters.name: source_node
parameters.description: The ID of the starting node.

parameters.name: target_node
parameters.description: The ID of the ending node.

parameters.name: edge_type
parameters.description: The type of edge the ACL inheritance path is being fetched for.

200.description: Returns graph data that contains a collection of nodes and edges that make up the ACL inheritance path.

get.description: Export an existing saved query by ID

200.description:
**OK**
This response will contain binary content.

The response ZIP file will contain JSON files using their query name as the file name.
The underlying JSON file is expected to have the following structure:
```json
{
 "name": "Return_Nodes",
 "query": "MATCH (n) RETURN n",
 "description": "Returns all nodes in a given graph"
}
```

post.summary: Import one or more cypher queries.
post.description:
Import one or more cypher queries.

The request body should be a json file containing a single query or a Zip consisting of multiple JSON files each containing a single query.

The underlying JSON file(s) is expected to have the following structure:
```json
{
 "name": "Return_Nodes",
 "query": "MATCH (n) RETURN n",
 "description": "Returns all nodes in a given graph"
}
```

requestBody.description: Request body should be a JSON or Zip file.

parameters.name: scope
parameters.description: Scope of saved queries, only the first scope parameter is used.

get.summary: Export one or more saved queries
get.description: Export existing saved queries using the scope parameter.

200.description:
**OK**
This response will contain binary content.

The response ZIP file will contain JSON files using their query name as the file name.
The underlying JSON file is expected to have the following structure:
```json
{
 "name": "Return_Nodes",
 "query": "MATCH (n) RETURN n",
 "description": "Returns all nodes in a given graph"
}
```

post.description: Runs a manual cypher query directly against the database

get.description:
Retrieves entity information for the given Azure object ID.
If `related_entity_type` parameter is not set, this endpoint will return information
about a single entity. Using the `counts` boolean parameter will further modify the response.
If `related_entity_type` parameter is set, this endpoint will return information about entities
related to a single entity. The `type` parameter will morph the response data structure. The `list`
value for the `type` parameter also accepts `skip` and `limit` parameters.

parameters.name: object_id
parameters.description: The object ID of the entity being operated on.

parameters.name: counts
parameters.description: Returns related entity counts. Does not work with `related_entity_type` parameter.

parameters.name: related_entity_type
parameters.description: Flags the query to return related entity information based on the type passed.

parameters.name: type
parameters.description: The type of return data expected. Only works with `related_entity_type` parameter.

parameters.name: skip
parameters.description:
This query parameter is used for determining the number of objects to skip in pagination.
Only compatible with `related_entity_type` and `type=list`

parameters.name: limit
parameters.description:
This query parameter is used for setting an upper limit of objects returned in paginated responses.
Only compatible with `related_entity_type` and `type=list`

schema.description: The limit of results requested by the client.

200.description:
This endpoint returns a polymorphic response dependent on the query parameters passed. Three
different response schemas are possible:
- **entity** schema is used when `related_entity_type` is not set. Additional 'count' properties are
  dependent on the type of entity being queried.
- **related-list** schema is used when `related_entity_type` is set and `type` parameter is either
  `list` or not set (it is the default), and it supports pagination.
- **related-graph** schema is used when `related_entity_type` is set and `type=graph`.

oneOf.title: entity
oneOf.description:
This response is used when `related_entity_type` is not set. It returns information
about a single node. All node types will return with the basic node fields, but the
additional count properties are dependent on the kind of node returned. Setting
`counts=true` will populate those count details at the cost of performance.

allOf.title: related-list
allOf.description:
This response is used when `related_entity_type` is set and the `type` parameter is
either `list` or not set (it is the default return type). It returns a list of related
entities and supports pagination parameters.

allOf.title: related-graph
allOf.description:
This response is used when `related_entity_type` is set and the `type` parameter is
set to `graph`. It returns graph data without a basic data response wrapper.

get.description: Get basic info and counts for this node.
Get a list, graph, or count of the principals this node can control.
Get a list, graph, or count of the principals that can control this node.
Get info and counts for this computer node.
Get a list, graph, or count of the systems this computer has admin rights to.
Get a list, graph, or count of the principals that have admin rights on this computer.

get.summary: Get computer entity constrained delegation rights
get.description: Get a list, graph, or count of the principals that this computer has constrained delegations rights to.
Get a list, graph, or count of the principals that have constrained delegation rights to this computer.

get.description:
Lists detailed data about attack paths for a domain.

__Note:__ `ImpactCount`, `ImpactPercentage`, `ExposureCount`, `ExposurePercentage` and `Severity` will have a value other than zero when butterfly analysis is enabled.

parameters.name: Accept
parameters.description: Media type to determine the response format (application/json or text/csv).

parameters.name: sort_by
parameters.description: Sortable columns are `domain_sid`, `index`, `AcceptedUntil`, `id`, `created_at`, `updated_at`, `deleted_at`, `exposure_percentage`, `impact_percentage`. Relationship risks can be sorted on `FromPrincipal` and `ToPrincipal` in addition to the sortable columns for List Risks.

Butterfly Relationship Finding.description: When the butterfly analysis feature flag is on, impact count/percentage and exposure count/percentage will have a value other than zero.

Metatree Relationship Finding.description: When the butterfly analysis feature flag is off and metatree is running, impact count/percentage and exposure count/percentage will have a value of zero.

Butterfly List Finding.description: When the butterfly analysis feature flag is on, impact count/percentage and exposure count/percentage will have a value other than zero.

Metatree List Finding.description: When the butterfly analysis feature flag is off and metatree is running, impact count/percentage and exposure count/percentage will have a value of zero.

get.description: List the values that represent the sparklines for individual attack paths

parameters.name: from
parameters.description: Beginning datetime of range (inclusive) in RFC-3339 format; Defaults to current datetime minus 30 days

parameters.name: to
parameters.description: Ending datetime of range (exclusive) in RFC-3339 format; Defaults to current datetime

put.description: Updates an attack path as an accepted or unaccepted risk until a given time.

requestBody.description: The request body for updating risk acceptance

header.prefer.name: Prefer
header.prefer.description: Prefer header, used to specify a custom timeout in seconds using the wait parameter as per RFC7240.

query.created-at.name: created_at
query.created-at.description: Filter results by `created_at` value. See filter schema details for valid predicates.

query.updated-at.name: updated_at
query.updated-at.description: Filter results by `updated_at` value. See filter schema details for valid predicates.

query.deleted-at.name: deleted_at
query.deleted-at.description: Filter results by `deleted_at` value. See filter schema details for valid predicates.

query.skip.name: skip
query.skip.description: This query parameter is used for determining the number of objects to skip in pagination.

query.limit.name: limit
query.limit.description: This query parameter is used for setting an upper limit of objects returned in paginated responses.

query.environments.name: environments
query.environments.description: Environment IDs to filter response by

path.object-id.name: object_id
path.object-id.description: The object id of the entity being operated on.

query.hydrate-counts.description: Include counts of related entities. Default value is `true`.
query.hydrate-counts.name: counts

query.entity.skip.name: skip
query.entity.skip.description: The number of entries to skip for pagination. Only available for `type=list`.

query.entity.limit.name: limit
query.entity.limit.description: The number of entries to limit in the response. Only available for `type=list`.

query.entity.type.name: type
query.entity.type.description:
The type of return data requested. If no type is provided, query will default to `list`.
The only supported type is `list`, but the unsupported `graph` type can be used.
Some entity query endpoints do not support the `graph` type. For those interested in
using the undocumented graph type parameter, the response type is described in the schema
`model.bh-graph.graph`.

query.entity.sort-by.name: sort_by
query.entity.sort-by.description:
Sort by column. Can be used multiple times; prepend a hyphen for descending order. Columns available
for sorting are dependent on the entity object kind.

query.asset-group-tag-id.name: asset_group_tag_id
query.asset-group-tag-id.description: The asset group tag id of the zone requested. If not supplied, the asset group tag id associated with 'Tier Zero' and 'Hygiene' is used.

query.clients.hydrate-domains.name: hydrate_domains
query.clients.hydrate-domains.description: When a value of `true` is passed, any Domains associated with scheduled and finished jobs for each client will have expanded properties including `name` and `type`. When a value of `false` is passed, these same Domains will only return as a list of `objectid`s.

query.clients.hydrate-ous.name: hydrate_ous
query.clients.hydrate-ous.description: When a value of `true` is passed, any OUs associated with scheduled and finished jobs for each client will have expanded properties including `name` and `type`. When a value of `false` is passed, these same OUs will only return as a list of `objectid`s.

context.description: The context in which the error took place

message.description: A human-readable description of the error

timestamp.description: The RFC-3339 timestamp in which the error response was sent

request_id.description: The unique identifier of the request that failed

errors.description: The error(s) that occurred from processing the request

id.description: This is the unique identifier for this object.

valid.description: Valid is true if `time` is not `null`.
Valid is true if `int32` is not `null`.

id.description: This is the unique identifier for this object.

valid.description: Valid is true if `string` is not `null`

user_id.description: The user UUID that associates the access control to a specific user

environment_id.description: The environment id which a user has been granted access to

sso_provider_id.description: ID of the SSO provider for this user

environment_targeted_access_control.description: A collection of environment targeted access controls that a user has been granted access to.

valid.description: Valid is true if `uuid` is not `null`.
Valid is true if `int64` is not `null`.

id.description: This is the unique identifier for this object.

enum.job-status.description:
This enum describes the current status of a Job. Values are:
- `-1` Invalid
- `0` Ready
- `1` Running
- `2` Complete
- `3` Canceled
- `4` Timed Out
- `5` Failed
- `6` Ingesting
- `7` Analyzing
- `8` Partially Complete

domain_name.description: Name of the domain that was enumerated

success.description: A boolean value indicating whether the domain enumeration succeeded

message.description: A status message for a domain enumeration result

deleted_count.description: A count of deleted objects enumerated

enum.client-type.description: This enum describes the collector client type.

id.description: Unique identifier for the SSO provider

type.description: Type of SSO provider (SAML or OIDC)

api.params.query.sort-by.description:
Sort by column. Can be used multiple times; prepend a hyphen for descending order.
See parameter description for details about which columns are sortable.

api.params.predicate.filter.string.description: Filter results by column string value. Valid filter predicates are `eq`, `~eq`, `neq`.

api.params.predicate.filter.integer.description: Filter results by column integer value. Valid filter predicates are `eq`, `neq`, `gt`, `gte`, `lt`, `lte`.

api.params.predicate.filter.time.description:
Filter results by column timestamp value formatted as an RFC-3339 string.
Valid filter predicates are `eq`, `neq`, `gt`, `gte`, `lt`, `lte`.

api.params.predicate.filter.uuid.description: Filter results by column string-formatted uuid value. Valid filter predicates are `eq`, `neq`.

sso_provider_id.description: ID of the SSO provider for this user

all_environments.description: Grants access to all environments for the user. This will clear a user's environment access control list, if it exists

environment_targeted_access_control.description: Sets an environment targeted access control on the user. When all_environments is set to true, a user's existing environment control is cleared and they are granted access to all environments. Administrators and Power Users may not have an ETAC list applied to them.

enum.mfa-activation-status.description: The activation status of multi-factor authentication on a BloodHound user.

api.params.query.skip.description: The number of items to skip in a paginated response.

api.params.query.limit.description: The limit of results requested by the client.

valid.description: Valid is true if `boolean` is not `null`

type.description: The type of selector, valid types are 1 - object id or 2 - cypher.

value.description: The string value representing either an objectid or cypher query depending on the selector type.

auto_certify.description: auto_certify must be an input value of 0 (Disabled), 1 (AllMembers), or 2 (SeedsOnly)

api.params.predicate.filter.integer-stri.description: Filter results by column integer value. Valid filter predicates are `eq`, `neq`.

api.params.predicate.filter.string-stric.description: Filter results by column string value. Valid filter predicates are `eq`, `neq`.

api.params.predicate.filter.boolean.description: Filter results by column boolean value. Valid filter predicates are `eq`, `neq`.

name.description: Only alphanumeric characters, underscores, and spaces are allowed.
Only alphanumeric characters, underscores, and spaces are allowed.

auto_certify.description: auto_certify must be an input value of 0 (Disabled), 1 (AllMembers), or 2 (SeedsOnly)

id.description: The graph ID of this node

certified.description: 0 = cert pending, 1 = cert revoked, 2 = manual cert, 3 = auto cert

api.params.predicate.filter.contains.description:
The contains predicate checks a property against the values in a given comma separated list.
- `in` checks if the property matches an element in the given comma separated list.
  - `in:Contains,GetChangesAll,MemberOf`
- `nin` checks if the property does not match an element in the given comma separated list.
  - `nin:LocalToComputer,MemberOfLocalGroup`

start.description: The RFC-3339 timestamp to describe the beginning of a time range

end.description: The RFC-3339 timestamp to describe the end of a time range

finding_assets.description: Directory structure of Base64 encoded assets related to each finding organized by finding name.

enum.posture-history-type.description: This enum describes the valid data types for posture history results.

bad-request.description:
**Bad Request**
This could be due to one of the following reasons:
- JSON payload is missing or malformed
- Path or query parameters are missing or invalid/malformed
- The data sent is not valid (ex- sending a `string` in an `integer` field)

errors.message: The JSON payload could not be unmarshalled.

unauthorized.description:
**Unauthorized**
This endpoint failed an authentication requirement. Either the client tried to access
a protected endpoint without being authenticated, or an auth validation failed (ex- invalid
credentials or expired token).

forbidden.description:
**Forbidden**
This is most commonly caused by an authenticated client trying to
access a resource that it does not have permission for.

errors.message: You do not have permission to access this resource

too-many-requests.description:
**Too Many Requests**
The client has sent too many requests within a certain time window
and tripped the rate limiting middleware.

errors.message: Too many requests. Please try again later.

internal-server-error.description:
**Internal Server Error**
This is usually the result of either an unexpected database or application error.
The client may try modifying or resending the request, but the error is likely not related to the client
doing something wrong.

errors.message: The request could not be handled due to an unexpected database error.

not-found.description:
**Not Found**
This error typically comes from operations where a valid ID was passed to the request
to look up an entity but the entity could not be found.

errors.message: The requested client could not be found.

no-content.description:
**No Content**
This response will contain no response body.

binary-response.description:
**OK**
This response will contain binary content.

unsupported-media-type.description:
**Unsupported Media Type**
Content-Type does not match expected formats.

errors.message: invalid content-type: [application/incorrect]; Content type must be application/json or application/zip

entity-info-query-results.description:
**OK**

This response is polymorphic and depends on the type of entity being queried and whether
the `count` param is true or not. All node types will return a `props` field with the graph node
properties and a `kinds` field with the graph node kinds. If `count=true` the response will also include additional fields with integer counts.

related-entity-query-results.description:
**OK**

This endpoint returns a response, dependent upon which return type is requested by the `type` parameter.
The only supported `type` parameter is `list`.
While `list` is the only supported `type` parameter, the `graph` parameter can be used
and will result in a different response structure then documented here.
For those interested in using the undocumented graph type parameter, the response type is described in the schema
`model.bh-graph.graph`.

csv-response.description:
**OK**
This response will contain csv text content.
